definition.primary: Meticulous surgical technique during carotid endarterectomy to identify and preserve the cranial nerves at risk in the operative field, including the vagus (X), hypoglossal (XII), glossopharyngeal (IX), marginal mandibular branch of facial (VII), and superior laryngeal nerve.
key_concepts: Cranial nerve injury occurs in 5-20% of CEA cases
Most injuries are temporary (neurapraxia) resolving in weeks to months
Vagus and hypoglossal nerves most commonly affected
Proper technique and anatomic knowledge minimize injury risk

anatomy.location: Posterior to carotid artery in carotid sheath, between ICA and IJV
anatomy.course: Descends from skull base to thorax

anatomy.location: Crosses ECA and ICA typically 2-3 cm above bifurcation
anatomy.course: Curves forward over ECA to tongue
anatomy.landmarks: Often crossed by occipital artery, sternocleidomastoid branch of occipital

injury_mechanism: Excessive retraction for distal ICA exposure
consequences: Ipsilateral tongue deviation toward affected side
prevention: Divide ansa cervicalis if needed (minimal morbidity)
Divide digastric tendon or stylohyoid for high exposure

anatomy.location: External branch descends along superior thyroid artery

prevention: Preserve superior thyroid artery when possible
Ligate STA flush with ECA if division needed

anatomy.location: Exits skull base, courses between ICA and IJV
anatomy.function: Sensory to pharynx, carotid body innervation

prevention: Usually not in operative field for standard CEA

anatomy.location: Branch of facial nerve, courses along mandible
anatomy.function: Motor to depressor muscles of lower lip

prevention: Place incision along anterior border of SCM, not higher

exposure_principles: Longitudinal incision along anterior SCM border
Early identification of IJV and carotid sheath
Identification of vagus posteriorly before carotid manipulation
Circumferential dissection with minimal adventitial stripping

for_distal_exposure: Divide posterior belly of digastric (can be repaired)
Mobilize hypoglossal nerve with surrounding tissue
Mandibular subluxation for very high lesions
for_proximal_exposure: Preserve superior thyroid artery when possible

principles: Minimize force on tissues containing nerves

techniques: Continuous EMG monitoring of vagus/recurrent laryngeal
Somatosensory evoked potentials (for cerebral, not cranial nerves)
intraoperative_monitoring.utility: Controversial; most surgeons rely on careful technique without monitoring

evaluation: Tongue protrusion (hypoglossal - deviates to injured side)
management_of_injury: Speech therapy referral if swallowing affected

outcomes.bilateral_procedures: Higher risk of significant deficits if contralateral nerve previously injured

learning_objectives: Identify the cranial nerves at risk during carotid endarterectomy
Describe the anatomic course of each nerve in the operative field
Apply surgical techniques to minimize nerve injury
Recognize clinical manifestations of each cranial nerve injury
key_points: Vagus and hypoglossal nerves most commonly injured in CEA
Most cranial nerve injuries are temporary (neurapraxia)
Excessive retraction is common mechanism of injury
Hypoglossal mobilization may be needed for distal ICA exposure
clinical_pearls: Always identify vagus before applying carotid clamps
Occipital artery often crosses hypoglossal - divide artery, preserve nerve
Tongue deviation toward affected side = hypoglossal injury
Hoarseness post-CEA may be from vagus (ETT) or recurrent laryngeal - get ENT evaluation
